mechanical properties of nano- and micro-particle reinforced composites. In this work, we devise a general micromechanical framework to predict the effective elastic moduli of particle-reinforced composites containing ellipsoidal nano- or micro-particles with varying interface properties (e.g., both hard and soft). Specifically, the interface is treated as an interphase perfectly bonding the particle and matrix with a finite thickness and volume fraction. The morphological characteristics of the interface (e.g., volume fraction) are quantified using a statistical geometry approach and subsequently incorporated into the Mori-Tanaka average scheme with Eshelby’s equivalent inclusion theory to derive the general micromechanical framework for the three-phase composites with non-spherical inclusions. We show that our new framework leads to predictions of the elastic moduli of a wide spectrum of nanoand micro-particle reinforced composites with both soft and hard interfaces to a reasonable accuracy by comparing with available experimental data and predictions from other theoretical frameworks. The general framework provides a robust and convenient predictive toolkit for composite design and evaluation. Keywords: Particle-reinforced composites; Interphase; Elastic properties; Anisotropy; Design.
 Correspondence to: Institute of Soft Matter Mechanics, College of Mechanics and Materials, Hohai University, Nanjing 211100, China. E-mail addresses: xuwenxiang@hhu.edu.cn (W. Xu) and yang.jiao.2@asu.edu (Y. Jiao).

1. Introduction
Interface is an important structural component in a variety of soft matter and particulate material
systems, such as nanocrystalline materials, polymers, colloids and cementitious composites [1-9]. Recent experimental and numerical investigations have shown that the interface zones can be considered as either a hard or soft (compliant) interphase in such materials, which plays an important role in their mechanical and transport properties [1-9]. In general, a hard interface zone is one that possess a high stiffness (e.g., due to the high mismatch stress at the particle-matrix interface in nanocomposites) and can be considered as impenetrable layers surrounding the particles that leads to improved mechanical properties of nanocomposites [1, 4]. For examples, hard interface zones are found in polymer nanocomposites such as polyamide 12/montmorillonite nanocomposites [1] and nylon 6/montmorillonite nanocomposites [4], as shown in Fig. 1(a). On the other hand, compliant interface zones typically possess low stiffness due to structural defects or relative high porosity at the particle-matrix interface, and can be considered as penetrable layers surrounding the particles that compromise the mechanical properties of the materials [5-8]. Soft interfaces have been found and studied in MXD6-clay nanocomposites [8] and cementitious composites (namely, interfacial transition zone, ITZ) [5, 7, 9], as shown in Fig. 1(b). As a crucial link between the reinforced nano-/micro-particles and matrix, understanding the effects of interfacial characteristics (say, thickness, volume fraction, stiffness etc.) on the effective elastic moduli of the composites and rigorously incorporating such interface information into homogenization scheme for material property predictions is a problem of great interest in materials research community. The resulting rigorous structure-property relations are also valuable for material design and microstructure optimization.
There are different interface models used in micromechanics of composites, such as the
linear-spring/-viscosity model [10-12], the stress model [13-15], the functionally graded model [16, 17] and the interphase model [5-7]. The first two models assumed that displacements and/or stresses are
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
discontinuous at the interface. Also, the interface is either regarded as a compliant layer (the first class) or a stiff layer (the second class) and occupies a zero volume in composites. The third class considered that the physical properties of the interface region surrounding spherical particles vary continuously with radial distance from local particle centers and satisfy a power law. Unlike the former three classes, the interphase model described an interface zone as a hard/compliant shell with a specific thickness (characteristics dimension) between the particles and matrix. This is the well-known “core-shell structure (HCSS)”. For this class of interphase models, perfect bonding conditions are normally assumed to at both the particles/interfaces and interfaces/matrix. In this case, the interfacial characteristics (e.g., thickness, volume fraction, stiffness etc.) and their effects on effective elastic properties of particle-reinforced composites should be explicitly considered and incorporated in micromechanical frameworks for such systems.
Over the past few decades, considerable efforts have been devoted to theoretically predicting the
effective moduli of particle-reinforced composites consisting of reinforced particles, interfaces and matrix. In the seminal work of Kerner [18], a three-phase model for composites with spherical particles was proposed to study the effective elastic properties. Later, Christensen and Lo [19] applied the generalized self-consistent scheme and the Eshelby’s equivalent inclusion theory [20] to evaluate the effective shear moduli of three-phase composites including spherical and cylindrical particles. On the other hand, on the basis of the well-known variational principle originally introduced in the pioneering work of Hashin and Shtrikman [21], Herve and Zaoui [22] extended the Christensen-Loʼs three-phase model to n-layered model. Nevertheless, such the n- layered model considered only spherical particles and the hard interphase (impenetrable layers) surrounding spherical particles, where the volume fraction of each phase is simply expressed as the third power of radius of the corresponding spherical layer (see Eq. (47) in the reference [22]). For particle reinforced composites containing ellipsoidal particles and interfaces, different micromechanical models have been further developed for
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
investigating their mechanical properties, including generalized self-consistent method (GSCM) [23, 24], Mori-Tanaka scheme (M-T) [25, 26], double-inclusion model [27], differential effective medium approximation (D-EMA) [28] and other effective medium methods [29-31]. Although these outstanding contributions may provide guidance for the effective moduli of particle-reinforced composites, structural characteristics of interfaces drawn into the abovementioned models are quite limited. As demonstrated by Torquato [29], the more structural characteristics of composite media are incorporated, the more accurate their effective physical properties of composites can be estimated. It is worth mentioning that Xu and coworkers [24, 32] recently utilized the combination of the variational principle with GSCM to investigate the effective conductivity and elastic moduli of micro-ellipsoidal particle reinforced composites, explicitly incorporating the volume fraction of soft interfaces. However, there is no a generalized micromechanical scheme explicitly incorporating hard and soft interfacial structural characteristics to accurately predict the effective elastic moduli of composites reinforced by nano- and micro-particle with non-spherical shapes. It is our intention in the present work to address this gap.
This paper attempts to develop a general micromechanical framework for understanding the
effects of volume fractions of hard or soft interface zones on the effective elastic moduli of heterogeneous nano- and micro-particle reinforced composites with non-spherical particle shapes. The Mori-Tanaka average scheme and the Eshelby’s equivalent inclusion theory are generalized to explicitly incorporate the interface characteristics for the prediction of the effective elastic moduli of heterogeneous particle-reinforced composites, consisting of a homogeneous matrix, anisotropic nanoor micro-sized ellipsoidal particles, and hard or soft interface zones. Perfect bonding conditions and the interphase model are used in this work. It is noted from Fig. 1 that ellipsoidal particles randomly dispersed in a homogeneous matrix possess the same geometric and mechanical configurations including the constant size, shape (i.e., the so-called monodisperse system) and elastic parameters. Plus,

their concentric interfacial layers with a constant dimension have the same geometric and mechanical features. Thus, random monodisperse particles can be viewed as a reinforced phase, which leads to a three-phase composite consisting of particles, matrix and interphase. The rest of this article is organized as follows. Section 2 demonstrates the general micromechanical framework for predicting the effective moduli of three-phase composites. In Section 3, some results on the comparisons of the framework with extensive experimental data from polymer nanocomposites, cementitious composites and asphalt concrete, and with other theoretical models are given and discussed. Finally, this article is completed with some concluding remarks in Section 4. 2. The general micromechanical framework

spheres (κ=1), the present framework resembles to the expressions of effective moduli for three-phase composites with spherical particles presented in the previous research [39], except for the parameter relating volume fraction of interfaces in those expressions. If Vi = 0, the present scheme further reduces to the well-known M-T [25, 26]. Additionally, the present framework can also be used to evaluate the effective moduli of fibrous composites and platelet composites by submitting of their Eshelby’s tensors S into Eq. (18), the derivations of which are displayed in Appendix A. It is worth stressing that our micromechanical framework provides a quantitative connection of the structural characteristics of interfaces, especially the thickness and volume fraction of hard or soft interfaces, with the effective moduli of three-phase composites, which is distinctively different from other theoretical models introduced in the previous popular works. 3. Results and discussion
Firstly, we use our micromechanical framework to predict the effective Young’s moduli of
nanoparticle reinforced composites with hard interfaces, such as nylon 6/montmorillonite nanocomposites composed of nylon 6/montmorillonite, reinforced interfaces and polymer. Fig. 3 presents the predicted results on the effective Young’s moduli of such three-phase nanocomposites that are compared with the experimental data reported by Ji et al. [4] and those predictions from other theoretical models like the differential effective medium approximation (D-EMA) [28] and the generalized self-consistent method (GSCM) developed by Xu et al. [32]. From Fig. 3, it can be clearly seen that the predicted elastic moduli through the present framework are excellent consistent with the experimental data, in other words, the developed micromechanical framework meets the expectation of the experimental study for the elastic properties of polymer nanocomposites. Although the tendency of the theoretical results from D-EMA and GSCM is in line with the experimental data, D-EMA and GSCM both overestimate the effective elastic moduli of polymer nanocomposites with respect to the experimental data, as shown in Fig. 3. It indicates that D-EMA and GSCM do not well adapt for the
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
prediction of effective elastic moduli of nanoparticle reinforced composites considering the role of hard interfaces.
In addition, we also compute the effective Young’s moduli of polymer nanocomposites without
hard interfaces (i.e., two-phase nanoparticle reinforced composites) using the framework, as shown in Fig. 3. We find that the predicted results are dramatically lower than the experimental data. As illustrated above, the present theoretical framework degenerates to the conventional double-inclusion model [27] as Vi = 0. This means that the conventional double-inclusion model underestimates the effective elastic moduli of polymer nanocomposites. More importantly, it confirms that the interfacial effect dominates the overall elastic moduli of nanoparticle reinforced composites and needs to be considered in the theoretical and modelling studies of the elastic properties of nanoparticle reinforced composites. Accordingly, we display the effect of the volume fraction of nanoparticles corresponding to polymer nanocomposites mentioned above on the hard interfacial volume fraction, as shown in Fig. 4. It can be clearly seen that the hard interfacial volume fraction increases with increasing nanoparticle volume fraction. Consequently, hard interfaces as a reinforced phase with respect to matrix must enhance the elastic moduli of nanoparticle-reinforced composites with increasing hard interfacial volume fraction.
Subsequently, we apply our micromechanical framework to evaluate the elastic moduli of
nanocomposites containing soft interfaces like nanoclay particle reinforced composites. Fig. 5 presents comparisons of the predicted effective Young’s moduli with the experimental data for MXD6-clay nanocomposites consisting of MXD6-nanoclay particles, polymer and compliant interfaces studied by Sheng et al. [40]. As expected, our theoretical framework provides a fantastic accuracy for the prediction of the Young’s moduli of polymer-clay nanocomposites, compared to the experimental data. It is also observed from Fig. 5 that D-EMA has an incremental gap for the estimation of the effective Young’s moduli of polymer-clay nanocomposites as the increase of the volume fraction of nanoclay
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
particles. Nevertheless, the theoretical predictions from GSCM are totally opposite to the experimental data, to be specific, the effective Young’s moduli of nanoclay particle reinforced composites calculated by GSCM are a monotonic attenuation function with the volume fraction of nanoclay particles, as shown in Fig. 5. It validates that GSCM is incapable of predicting the effective elastic moduli of nanoparticle reinforced composites containing hard or soft interfaces. Plus, Fig. 5 displays the theoretical results on the effective Young’s moduli of two-phase polymer-clay nanocomposites without soft interfaces using the proposed micromechanical framework. It can be seen that the predicted Young’s moduli of two-phase nanocomposites are apparently higher than the experimental data, due to the fact that the existence of compliant interfaces as a weak phase with low rigidity weakens the overall mechanical properties of practical polymer-clay nanocomposites. In addition, the dependence of the soft interfacial volume fraction on the volume fraction of nanoparticles is also given in Fig. 6. One can see that the soft interfacial volume fraction increases with increasing nanoparticle volume fraction. Therefore, it is necessary to draw into the interface features in the theoretical and numerical estimations of physical properties of nanoparticle reinforced composites.
We further apply our micromechanical framework to estimate the effective elastic moduli of
micro-particle reinforced composites like normal concrete and asphalt concrete, where interfacial transition zones with a relative high porosity extensively exist. Interfacial transition zones are usually convinced as soft interfaces in those civil engineering materials. Fig. 7 presents comparisons of the predictions with the experimental data for normal concrete composed of aggregates, cement paste and interfacial transition zones [39]. We can see that the predicted results from the present model and GSCM developed by our preliminary work are in good agreement with the experimental data. D-EMA yet slightly overestimates the effective Young’s moduli relative to the experimental data. Also, compared to the theoretical results from the present two-phase prediction irrespective of interfaces, the predicted results from three-phase schemes are closer to the experimental data, especially for the high
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
volume fraction of aggregates, as shown in Fig. 7. It elucidates that the interfacial effect becomes more sensitive with the increase of the volume fraction of aggregates. As an explanatory reason, Fig. 8 depicts the change of the soft interfacial volume fraction with the volume fraction of aggregates. We can see that the soft interfacial volume fraction increases when the volume fraction of aggregates increases up to about 0.6. Then, as the volume fraction of aggregates grows, the soft interfacial volume fraction yet gradually decreases. Actually, interfaces completely occupy to the remaining matrix as the volume fraction of aggregates increases to about 0.6. Thus, when the volume fraction of aggregates continues to increase, some interfacial zones are occupied by the increased aggregates, so that the interfacial volume fraction gradually decreases when the volume fraction of aggregates exceeds 0.6.
Moreover, we use the proposed theoretical framework, D-EMA and GSCM to evaluate the
effective Young’s moduli of asphalt concrete composed of aggregates, asphalt matrix and interfacial transition zones. The computed results are compared with the experimental data reported by Wang et al. [41], as shown in Fig. 9. We find that the predictions from our micromechanical framework are basically consistent with the experimental data. Nevertheless, GSCM and D-EMA both overestimate the effective Young’s moduli of asphalt concrete. Fig. 9 also shows that two-phase predictions without interfaces are apparently higher than the experimental data and three-phase predictions. It reveals that the interfacial effect as a distinct physical feature broadly exists in the internal structure of asphalt concrete and weakens its mechanical properties. Fig. 10 further shows the variation of the soft interfacial volume fraction with the volume fraction of aggregates in asphalt concrete. As expected, the soft interfacial volume fraction increases with increasing the volume fraction of aggregates. Therefore, From Figs. 3-10, we can believe that the feasibility of the general micromechanical framework proposed above at nano- and micro-scopic scales considering the roles of hard and soft interfaces. 4. Conclusions
In summary, we have developed a general micromechanical framework in details to incorporate
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
the properties of hard and soft interfaces into the effective elastic moduli of nano- and micro-particle reinforced composites. The novel micromechanical framework addressed how the hard and soft interfacial structural characteristics dominate quantitatively the overall elastic moduli of a wide spectrum of nano- and micro-particle reinforced composites. By comparing with extensive experimental data and other theoretical approximations, the present framework possessed a fantastic accuracy that cannot only be used to predict the overall elastic moduli of nanoparticle reinforced composites containing hard and soft interfaces, but also be applied to estimate the overall elastic moduli of micro-particle reinforced composites including soft interfaces. The general micromechanical framework can provide significant insights on optimizing the geometric configurations of reinforced particles and the physical characteristics of interfaces for the design of nano- and micro-particle reinforced composites. Figure Captions: Fig.1. Schematic views for three-phase composite structures with reinforced particles, matrix and (a) hard interfaces (gray impenetrable layers) and (b) soft interfaces (transparent penetrable layers). Fig.2. Schematic view for the predictions of the three-phase model using by the coupling of Mori-Tanaka scheme and Eshelby’s equivalent inclusion theory. Fig.3. The normalized effective Young’s moduli for polymer nanocomposites with hard interfaces predicted by the proposed scheme (black line), D-EMA and GSCM and that for two-phase polymer nanocomposites without interfaces (blue line). Basic parameters follow the experiment [4], such as E m = 509 MPa, E i = 12E m , E p = 40E m , ν m = 0.28, ν p = ν i = 0.1, κ = 3.21, Deq = 25 nm and t = 15 nm. Fig.4. Effect of the volume fraction of nanoparticles on the hard interfacial volume fraction. Basic parameters follow that displayed in Fig. 3. Fig.5. The normalized effective Young’s moduli for nanoclay reinforced composites containing soft interfaces computed by the present scheme (black line), D-EMA and GSCM and that for two-phase nanoclay composites without interfaces (blue line). Basic parameters follow the experiment [40], such as E m = 4 GPa, E i = 0.1E m , E p = 80E m , ν m = ν i = 0.35, ν p = 0.2, κ = 150, Deq = 2.84 nm and t = 1.5 nm. Fig.6. Effect of the volume fraction of nanoparticles on the soft interfacial volume fraction in polymer-clay nanocomposites. Basic parameters follow that displayed in Fig. 5. Fig.7. The normalized effective Young’s moduli for normal concrete containing interfacial transition zones calculated by the present scheme (black line), D-EMA and GSCM and that for two-phase cementitious composites without interfacial transition zones (blue line). Basic parameters follow Yangʼs experiment [39] that E m = 20.76 GPa, E i = 0.1E m , E p = 80 GPa, ν m = 0.2, ν i = 0.3, ν p = 0.21, κ = 3, Deq = 450 μm and t = 40 μm. Fig.8. Effect of the volume fraction of aggregates on the soft interfacial volume fraction in normal concrete. Basic parameters follow that displayed in Fig. 7.

Highlights
1. A general model for elastic moduli of nano-/micro-particle composites (N/MPCs). 2. N/MPCs contain nonspherical particles with varying hard/soft interface properties. 3. The general micromechanical framework (GMF) has a reasonable accuracy. 4. GMF incorporates hard and soft interfaces into the elastic properties of N/MPCs. 5. The derived results provide a robust predictive toolkit for the design of N/MPCs.

metadata.abstractText: The morphological and physical properties of interfaces can significantly affect the overall mechanical properties of nanoand micro-particle reinforced composites. In this work, we devise a general micromechanical framework to predict the effective elastic moduli of particle-reinforced composites containing ellipsoidal nanoor micro-particles with varying interface properties (e.g., both hard and soft). Specifically, the interface is treated as an interphase perfectly bonding the particle and matrix with a finite thickness and volume fraction. The morphological characteristics of the interface (e.g., volume fraction) are quantified using a statistical geometry approach and subsequently incorporated into the Mori-Tanaka average scheme with Eshelby’s equivalent inclusion theory to derive the general micromechanical framework for the three-phase composites with non-spherical inclusions. We show that our new framework leads to predictions of the elastic moduli of a wide spectrum of nanoand micro-particle reinforced composites with both soft and hard interfaces to a reasonable accuracy by comparing with available experimental data and predictions from other theoretical frameworks. The general framework provides a robust and convenient predictive toolkit for composite design and evaluation.
